thread.title: Confidence falls on China, Greece concerns
thread.title_full: Confidence falls on China, Greece concerns

author: news.com.au
title: Confidence falls on China, Greece concerns
text:
CONSUMER confidence has slipped to its lowest level in a year, on the back of anxiety about China's stockmarket and Greek debt.
THE ANZ-Roy Morgan consumer confidence index slid 3.6 per cent in the week ending July 12, following a 4.6 per cent fall the previous week, taking it to a 12-month low.
The slump was driven by eight per cent falls in respondents' views about the economic outlook for next year, and the next five years. Confidence for the next five years is now its lowest since the weekly series began in October 2008. ANZ chief economist Warren Hogan said there had been a fast retreat in confidence over the past two weeks. "The rapid turnaround in sentiment highlights the sensitivity of consumers towards both domestic and global conditions," Mr Hogan said. "Chinese stock market volatility and current negotiations surrounding Greece have dominated the news flow over the past two weeks and spilled over into the local sharemarket." Overnight, eurozone leaders finally inked a fresh bailout deal to prevent debt-stricken Greece from crashing out of the euro. After 17-hours of talks, leftist Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras accepted terms set by his international creditors for a third bailout.
